title: America has a long history of Christian Great Awakenings. What are the chances of a new Great Awakening in the foreseeable future? - Quora
tags: History of the United States of America

response.answer_text: I believe a great awakening can happen. Many Christians of different denominations want and pray and are working for an awakening. My opinion, though, is that one of the obstacles for such an awakening is the way many Christians go about evangelizing and spreading the Gospel. We all know that Christianity is declining in the United States. A report last month by Pew Forum revealed a 12 percent drop since 2009 in the number of Americans who identify as Christian, from 77 percent to 65 percent. It was even worse among Millennials. Only 49 percent of that generation now identify as Christian. Many Protestant churches, and even some Catholic churches, are attempting to reach out to young people using modern entertainment. They host rock concerts and parties, replacing the traditional ways of worship for “cooler,” more “modern” ways, In the hopes that this will attract young people. I know that these people’s intentions are good, but what they are doing doesn’t seem to be working very well, does it? Christianity is still declining at a rapid pace, despite these churches attempts to be “cool.” Or maybe it is declining in part because of these attempts. According to Pew Forum, while Christianity has been on the decline in the U.S, Islam has been growing. Something about Muslim worship is drawing people. Muslims don’t try to be cool, or to “keep up with the times.” Their hold to their old traditions of solemn worship, and that kind of worship seems to be resonating with people.  I should also point out the according to the same Pew report that I mentioned above, while Protestantism and Catholicism are both declining, Protestantism is declining faster. The percentage of Protestants has dropped 9 percent since 2009, while the percentage of Catholics only dropped 3 percent. The Catholics generally have stuck to more traditional types of worship then Protestants. So my contention is this: Most people don’t want “modern worship” in their churches. If people want to go to a rock concert, they are not going to go to a Church. If people want spiritual guidance, they are not going to go to a rock concert. What people want is meaning in their lives. They want to know that what they are doing is worthwhile. They want substance. For evidence of this, look no further then the rise of Jordan Peterson. Like him or not, you have to admit that with his lectures about taking responsibility and living a meaningful life, this man has hit a nerve with young people today. What I am saying is that people want meaningful lives. And that includes meaningful worship. Not shallow entertainment. There is a time and place for that, and the place is not in the church. Like it or not, many Christians have let today’s young people down. Unintentionally, of course, but nevertheless, they have. If we want a Spiritual Awakening, we have to return to meaningful worship. To tradition. Because that’s what people crave, and that’s what people need.
